results.title: Jazz mania
results.creator_credit: Chris Hubbard and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: This production takes a look at the impact of Jazz on people and society when it was firstly introduced in the 1920’s. Incorporating archival footage with dramatised scenes resembling newsreels of the time, the film documents the shock and consternation registered by polite society.

results.title: Jazz in the concert hall. Parts 1 and 2
results.creator_credit: Roger Englander and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description: Leonard Bernstein explains and illustrates the nature of jazz and its fusion with serious concert music since the 1920’s. Includes three major works performed by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and soloists to illustrate this fusion: Gunther Schuller’s “Journey into jazz” featuring jazz musicians Don Ellis (Itrumpet), Eric Dolphy (alto sax), Benny Golsen (tenor sax), Richard Davis (bass) and Joseph Cocuzzo (drums); Aaron Copland’s “Concerto for piano and orchestra”; Larry Austin’s “Improvisations for orchestra and jazz soloists”.

results.title: Japanese: language and people. [kit]
results.creator_credit: Brian Moeran, Richard Smith, Terry A. Doyle, Trevor Hughes Parry, BBC and Intervoice Incorporated
results.brief_description: This excellent kit comprising of five audio cassettes, a teacher manual and student reference book is designed to accompany the ‘Japanese: language and people’ videos. The tapes contain dialogues, exercises and practice material which is closely integrated to the course book. The teacher’s manual contains lesson suggestions in order to provide a strong framework for learning the language, while the course book provides an accessible introduction to the written language along with insights into contemporary Japanese society.

results.title: Japanese women [Short version]
results.creator_credit: Kalle Lasn, Don Hopkins, George Johnson, John Taylor and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A film that examines the changing roles and problems of women in Japan at a time in Japanese and Western societies when the nature of the family is undergoing rapid change and women’s role in society is being redefined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kalle Lasn, Don Hopkins, George Johnson, John Taylor and ONF | NFB

results.title: Japanese women
results.creator_credit: Kalle Lasn, Don Hopkins, John Taylor and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A film for those seeking insight into contemporary Japanese society, this one-hour documentary examines the status of women in Japan. Through a well-balanced blend of archival footage, candid interviews and fly-on-the-wall scenes of women at home and in the workplace, it investigates Japanese lifestyles, social values, labor practices and the women’s movement. A film highly recommended for students of Sociology and Far Eastern and Women’s Studies, as well as for those who intend to visit or do business with Japan. Related films: Japan Inc: Lessons for North America?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kalle Lasn, Don Hopkins, John Taylor and ONF | NFB

results.title: Japanese woman
results.creator_credit: Kalle Lasn, Don Hopkins, John Taylor, ONF | NFB and Psychomedia Productions
results.brief_description: After the 1945 surrender of the Japanese state to the Allies, the influence of United States administration saw Japan rapidly become one of the leading industrial nations in the world. The post-war Constitution gave women the right to vote and since that time Japanese feminism has attempted to question the structure of gender relations in their society without advocating an extreme Western individualism. This documentary examines the changes to Japanese society since World war II and focuses on the daily experiences of women at work, women in the home, and women in education and government. The documentary also examines the history of the women’s movement in Japan, and through the voices of Japanese feminists themselves, breaks down traditional stereotypes surrounding the “passivity” of Japanese women. The program features short interviews with feminists Kate Millet and with Misako Enoki.

results.title: Japanese ways, Western means: art of the 1980's in Japan
results.creator_credit: Museum of Modern Art (Japan, Saitama) and Queensland Art Gallery
results.brief_description: This exhibition, organised by the Queensland Art Gallery in association with the Museum of Modern Art, Saitama, presents work in a variety of media by 41 artists. Includes painting, sculpture, printmaking, drawing, video, photography and installation art. The theme is the adoption by contemporary Japanese artists of an international approach combining Japanese roots and content with stylistic and aesthetic elements derived from Western art.

results.title: Japanese gestures
results.creator_credit: Michael Noonan and New South Wales. Dept. of Education. Learning Materials Production Centre
results.brief_description: Demonstrates Japanese body gestures used in communicating, with a later comparison to the equivalent Australian gesture. It is divided into 14 sections and demonstrates gestures commonly used in communication by the Japanese and is useful for students studying the language.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Noonan and New South Wales. Dept. of Education. Learning Materials Production Centre
